university-resources/current/glm-2/hw/hw.title: HW 1
university-resources/current/glm-2/hw/hw.description:
Descriptive statistics describe the state of the data. It summarizes and describes the characteristics of a data set whereas inferential statistics infer information about the sample participants based on their data. Inferential statistics uses data from a sample to make predictions or draw conclusions about a larger population. The results allow us to analyze the sample and infer predictions about the larger population. The General Linear Model (GLM) Assumes the residuals (variation of variables) will be 'normally distributed' Betas are regression weights that are optimally estimated based on their contribution of each variable to reasonable predictions of Y. Absolute value of b depends on the metric scale of the x variable that they modify
The Generalized Linear Model (GLzM) Extension of GLM Outcome variable follows different distributions than the 'normal distribution' (i.e., probability distributions, binomial distributions, gamma distributions, etc.) Binary/dichotomous, count data, etc. Outcome variable is traditionally related to the linear model through link functions. Categories that are distinct and which do not have numerical value Examples School Eye color Marital status Numerical values that only signify ranking. Examples Risk level Likert-scale questions Numerical data that has equibalent ranges between values but no meaningful zero. Examples SAT scores Percentile rankings Temperature in Fahrenheit or Celsius Same as interval, but with a meaningful zero. Data can be ranked, intervals are consistent. Examples Height Age Weight Temperature in Kelvin
A One-Way Independent ANOVA Add a period at the end of the statements. The text should turn from red to blue and he should be able to run the selected lines of code.

university-resources/current/glm-2/hw/hw.title: HW 2
university-resources/current/glm-2/hw/hw.description:
The change in the dependent (outcome) variable for a one unit change in the independent (predictor) variable, while holding all other variables constant. Expressed in the original units of the dependent (outcome) and independent (predictor) variables. The values obtained after standardizing all variables (both dependent and independent variables) to have a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1. This allows for the newly calculated variables to represent the change in the dependent variable (in standard deviations) for one-standard deviation change in the value of the independent variable. Measures the relationship between two variables without controlling for any other variable(s) using simple correlation. We would use this when we want to understand the simple bivariate relationship between two variables. We would likely use the Pearson Correlation Coefficient R for this type of analysis. Measures the correlation between x and y while controlling for x2 (on both x and y). We would likely use this when we want to understand the direct relationship between two variables, independent of influence of other variables. Measures the relationship between two variables while controlling for the effect of one or more variables on only one of the two variables. Correlation between x and y while controlling for x2 (on x1 only) We would likely use this when we want to understand the exact contribution of an independent (predictor) variable to the dependent (outcome) variable, after taking into account the influence of other variables on the independent (predictor) variable. All predictors are added into the regression model at the same time. The model evaluates the contribution of each predictor to the outcome variable while controlling for all other predictors. R-squared is a static value that represents the variance explained in the outcome variable by the collective set of predictors. Continuous variable is added as it is
Nominal Variable must be dummy coded Variables with non-zero values should be ‘centered’ Predictors are entered into the model in a pre-specified order based theory-driven blocks. The model is built in blocks (steps) with each block adding one or more predictors. The change in the model’s R-squared is assessed at every step. A series of multiple-regression are performed, with each block being added to the next until all variables are included in the model. The final block of hierarchical multiple regression = simultaneous multiple regression. Very useful to look at the change in R-squared for each variable or blocks of variables Allow for testing hypotheses in the order of importance/priority of predictors. Squared semi-partial correlation provides the unique variance explained by a given variable. Predictors are added/removed from the model based on statistical criteria such as p-values or R-squared change rather than being theory-driven. Predictors are added/removed in data-driven blocks. Mathematically derives the highest R-squared value with the least number of predictors. CAUTION: NEVER USE THIS METHOD UNLESS STUDY IS ABSOLUTELY EXPLORATORY. Most predictive variables are added first Least predictive variables are removed first When you square the semi-partial correlation, it yields the proportion of the variance of y uniquely explained by x while controlling for all other predictors. Analyze > Regression > Linear Move dependent variable to Dependent. Move independent variable(s) to the Independent(s). - In Statistics, select Estimates (under Regression Coefficients), Model Fit, Descriptives, and Durbin-Watson (under Residuals, independence of errors). Click Continue. - In Plots, select Histograms and Normal Probability Plot (under Standardized Residual Plots). Move ZPRED under Y. Move ZRESID to X. Click Continue. - In Save, select Cook’s (under Distances). Click Continue. 3.     Click OK. The relationship between the independent (predictor) variables and the dependent (outcome) variables is linear. How to Check Use Scatterplots to visualize relationships. Click Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot. Click Simple Scatter. Click Define. Move your dependent variable (outcome) to the Y-Axis. Move your independent variable (predictor) to the X-Axis. If the scatterplot is approximately linear, the assumption is met. If not linear, apply transformation. Observations are independent of each other (no autocorrelation, where observations are NOT independent) How to Check Use the Durbin-Watson test by clicking the option under Linear Regression: Statistics. If the Durbin-Watson test falls within the range of 1.5 – 2.5, the assumption is met.
If data is autocorrelated, use alternative models such as the generalized least squares (GLS) model. The residuals (errors) have constant variance across all levels of independent variable(s). How to Check Plot residuals vs. predicted values and look for a random scatter. In SPSS, request Linear Regression Plots. Move Y > ZPRED. Move X > ZRESID. If the scatterplots shows no overall pattern, the assumption is met. If assumption is violated, you can transform the dependent variable, use standard errors, or apply weighted least squares (WLS). The residuals (errors) are normally distributed. How to Check (For None or One Grouping Variable) Click Analyze > Descriptives > Explore Transfer the variable that needs to be tested for normality into the Dependent List box. Click on Statistics. Leave Descriptives selected. Click the Plots. Select Factor Levels Together under Boxplots. Select Stem-and-Leaf under Descriptive. Select Normality Plots with Tests. Click Continue. Click OK. Check Shapiro-Wilk Test of Normality, Normal P-P Plot, Histogram, and Skewness/Kurtosis. If the Sig. value of the Shapiro-Wilk Test is greater than p = .05, the data is normal. If it is below .05, the data significantly deviate from a normal distribution. If the points are generally along the diagonal of the Normal P-P Plot, the assumption is met. If the Histogram is approximately normal (distribution curve is bell-shaped), the assumption is met. If Skewness and Kurtosis are between +2 and -2, the assumption is met. How far a case is from some point of reference
Identifies the distance of cases from the mean (s) of predictor (s). Extreme cases in multivariate space are found via a cut-off point (critical value of Chi-Square Test) Measure the distance between an observed value and its predicted value that have all been converted to z-scores. Typically flag cases if they are 2 or 3 standard deviations away from the mean. How far a point deviates from the mean of that variable. Gauges the influence of the observed values over the predicted values. Ranges from zero to (N – 1) / N Average value is (k + 1) / N No greater than 2 (k + 1) / N or 3 (k + 1) / N The degree to which a variable can ‘pull’ the regression towards itself.
Cook's Distance Measures the overall influence of a case on the model Typically flagged if value is over 1 Factor loadings help determine which variable is associated with which latent factor. For example, several likert-scale questions on a questionnaire observing psychological outcomes may load highly on a ‘depressive/depression’ factor, showing they measure the same underlying construct. Higher values of factor loadings (e.g., > .4 or .5) indicate that a variable is a strong indicator of that factor. Lower values suggest the variable is less relevant to that factor. EFA can allow us to group variables with higher factor loadings on the same factor, reducing the complexity of our data.
3 The eigenvalue represents the amount of variance explained by each factor. If using the eigenvalue cutoff of 1, the cutoff is greater than 1 because the retained factors explain more variance. This can be seen on the Scree plot where there is a point where the slope of the curve changes, which is usually the cutoff for the number of factors we would retain. Factors to the left of the cutoff are considered meaningful. This is why there are only 3 out of the original 12 factors that were extracted from the analysis. The first three factors account for more of the variance in the model.

university-resources/current/glm-2/hw/hw.title: HW 3
university-resources/current/glm-2/hw/hw.description: A moderator is a variable that affects the strength or direction of the relationship between an independent variable (x) and a dependent variable (y). A mediator is a variable that explains the mechanisms or process through which an independent variable (x) affects a dependent variable (y). The purpose of the ‘seed’ option in a line of PROCESS syntax is to lock the random number generator. This ensures that the findings remain consistent across multiple runs of the analysis. Without specifying a ‘seed’ value, the random number generator would draw different values each time, leading to slightly different results. When a covariable absorbs variable from both the predictor and the error term, it can lead to: Sphericity is an assumption in repeated measures ANOVA that states the variance of the differences between all pairs of within-subject conditions (levels of the independent variable) should be equal. This means that if we have three time points (A, B, C), then the variance of (A – B) ≈ variance of (A – C) ≈ variance of (B – C). Sphericity is a special case of homogeneity of variance assumption and is specific to repeated measures designs. Potential Consequences of Violating Sphericity Inflated Type I Errors Rate (False Positives) Standard F-tests assume sphericity, so violating it increases the risk of finding a significant effect when none actually exists. The p-values become too small, leading to incorrect conclusions. Reduced Statistical Power (False Negative) If sphericity is violated and not corrected, the test might be too conservative, making it harder to detect real effects (Type II Error: Failing to detect a true effect). Distorted F-ratios The denominator degrees of freedom in the F-test get inflated which makes the ANOVA test statistics biased. This impacts the accuracy of hypothesis testing. Long-Format Data

university-resources/current/glm-2/in-cl.description:
Logistic Regression When the outcome is dichotomous
Multinomial Logistic Regression When the outcome is categorical with more than two categories
Ordinal Logistic Regression When the outcome is ordinal Proportional odds or continuation ratio models
Poisson Regression and Negative Binomial Regression When the outcome is count data
Analytical Decision Tree for GLM Descriptive Statistics Descriptive statistics 'describe' the state of the data. More clear-cut, though with data transformation this can become complex. Inferential Statistics Inferential statistics 'infer' information about the participants based on their data. Can be descriptive but also predictive. 'Frequentist' Inferences Statistical inferences based on frequencies of probabilities.
Basis for Null Hypothesis statistical testing (NHST), statistical significance, Confidence Intervals, etc.
Nominal Variable or Nominal Variable Categories that are distinct and which do not have numerical value (e.g., school)
Ordinal Variables Numerical values that only signify ranking (e.g., risk level)
Interval Variable Numerical data that has equivalent ranges between values but no meaningful zero (e.g., SAT scores, percentile rankings, etc.)
Ratio Variable Same as interval, but with a meaningful zero (e.g., final exam scores) Linear = additive General model = linear in the parameters
Expected that the variation of variables will be 'normally distributed' (Normal Distribution) Beta's (b's) are regression weights that are optimally estimated based on their contribution of each variable to reasonable predictions of Y. Absolute value of b depends on the metric scale of the x variable that they modify.
Extension of the GLM The outcome variable follows different distributions I.e., probability distributions, binomial distributions, gamma distribution, poisson distributions, etc.
The outcome variable is non-linear (not continuous) Binary/dichotomous, count data, etc. The outcome variable is traditionally related to the linear model through link functions (such as transformations)

What are your research questions/hypotheses? Is your design correlational, experimental, or quasi-experimental? Is your study cross-sectional or longitudinal? Are assumptions of analyses being met a priori?
Regression Analysis Linearly related and normally distributed
Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) Independent observations, normally distributed, homogeneity (equal) variance across groups Familiarity with the dataset of your choosing How many cases? How many variables? Levels of measurement? Who are the participants? Is data identifiable? If not, is there a classification system in place? Any special considerations? Two methods of navigating SPSS Point and click Syntax A combination of both methods can produce a highly efficient (and less stressful) experience when using the software. Point and click menus are intuitive and clear for new users Syntax allows for a record of what has been done that can be easily reproduced and communicated with peers. Data editor See your data and variables directly Can carry out statistical functions Output viewer See the results of your analyses Syntax editor Enter text commands directly or save them from the data editor Analyze -> Descriptives -> Paste Formatting All statements end in a period (red text = bad; blue text = good) Comment to yourself by starting a line with * and end with a period . Not case-sensitive You can highlight any or all of a command to run it Structure Use the numeric lines to keep track of things Order the syntax logically and be sure to categorize! Using the Point and click method to create the desired syntax Descriptive statistics of variable(s) Analyze -> Descriptives -> Descriptives Using syntax File -> New -> Syntax Click on Window -> Designated Syntax Window Example Compute variable from existing variable Subtracting 1 from the value of the variables such as 'Whether mom graduated HS' with the original values being 1 'did not graduate' and 2 'graduated HS' to create dummy variable. COMPUTE hs_adj = mom_hs - 1 COMPUTE age_squared = mom_age**2 To square a value in syntax, include a double star (**) and 2 EXECUTE Highlight the computations and click RUN Commenting on Syntax Type the asterisks sign * computing new variable from an existing variable Even if the comments are highlighted, they will not be executed since they are just comments. To recode a variable (You can also do it manually from the variable view) RECODE mom_hs (2=1)(1=0) into new_mom_hs VARIABLE LABELS new_mom_hs "new mother's high school status" EXECUTE To create descriptive statistics DESCRIPTIVES VARIABLES mom_age kid_score /STATISTICS = MEAN STDDEV MIN MAX Highlight the computations and click RUN To create new group variable from existing variable (replacing variables with dummy coding) IF mom_age > 20 Mom_over = 1 IF mom_age <= 20 Mom_over = 0
Upper left quadrant is the 'Source' Upper right quadrant is the 'Environment/History' Lower left quadrant is the 'Console' Lower right quadrant are the 'Files/Plots/Packages/Help/etc.'
This just looks like a notebook where you write your code You can save this and share the file with your project mates You can make comments by beginning a line of code with '#' You can call it your R Script/Source You can create a new script by clicking the green '+' symbol on the top left corner and selecting 'R Script' To run a particular line of code, click 'run' or use 'Command + return' for Macbook and 'Control + Enter' for Windows
This is your 'Console' This is where the code you run from the source gets evaluated You can directly type your code here and get it evaluated, but the code will not be on your source/R Script
Shows all objects in your working space (e.g., your data, matrices, vector, functions, etc.) You can import data directly by using the 'Import Dataset' You can use the 'Broom' to clear all objects from the workspace.
You see your file directories You can view your plots You can see your 'Packages' and also install new packages You can read more about the function under 'Help' Make sure your Source file (R Script) and your dataset are saved (or located) in the same folder on your computer Set your working directory Steps: Click 'Session' -> Choose 'Set Working Directory' -> Select 'To Source File Location' First approach Click on 'Files' -> Select 'Import Dataset' -> Choose the data you want to import (e.g., Excel, SPSS data, STATA data, etc.) Second approach Click on 'Import Dataset' under 'ENVIRONMENT' -> Choose the data you want to import (e.g., Excel, SPSS data, STATA data, etc.) R comes with some functions which are free to use (e.g., mean (), sd ()) You do not need to install any package before using those functions However, to access a function written by others (other than the original 'authors' of R), you first have to install it as a 'package.' These packages often come with dataset(s), functions, examples, etc. Install a package using 'install.Packages ('name of the package)')' You need to install the package once and it will be on your computer permanently. After installing a package, you need to load it before having access to its functions, datasets, etc. Use 'library(name of package)' to load a package. There are many functions to explore your data View to have a quick view of your data Head to print out the first 6 rows Tail to print out the last 6 rows Summary to look at the summary of all your variables Psych::describe to check the descriptive statistics Use the dollar sign ($) to help select a specific variable E.g., mean(kids_score $age) will compute the mean for the variable age in the 'kids_score' dataset mean() to find the mean of a variable sd() to find the standard deviation var() to find variance sum() to find the totals Use '?' to learn more about a function nrow(data) to find the number of rows ncol(data) to find the number of columns colnames(data) to print the names of the columns (variables) str(data) to look at the structure of the variables
table() to print out the frequency in each group for a Nominal Variable min() and max() to find the minimum and maximum of a variable

university-resources/current/glm-2/in-cl.title: 2. Multiple Regression Review
university-resources/current/glm-2/in-cl.description:
Method of minimizing overall error in a particular model by producing estimates that have the least ' Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) ' (SSE = the sum of squared residual effects). Residual effects Unexplained variation in the outcome variable Error can be positive or negative, but negative residual is illogical, so we square the residuals. Best estimates for the b's are the one's that provide minimal error over any other collection of b's. The model with the smallest SSE will be the best fitting model.



The model with the smallest Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) will be the best fitting model
Least squares regression line
These values will always give us the smallest overall error, compared to any other line draw through the set of points.
Partitioning sum of squares into regression (explained) and error (unexplained)
Partitioning sum of squares into between (explained) and within/error (unexplained)
Testing regression coefficient
- T-test is based on the F-Tests (t-squared). We are testing if the beta weight of the coefficient is big enough to account for variation in Y compared to error.
- Error in estimate = Standard Error
Omnibus test How well does the model fit the actual data? Good fit Minimized error and strong correspondence between observed and predicted values (e.g., a large R-squared) F MSR / MSE provides overall statistical test of model fit H0 (Null Hypothesis) (x variable (s) do not predict y) With no better predictions than population mean of y H1 (Alternative Hypothesis) (x variable (s) do predict y) with better predictions than population mean of y. Mathematically accounting for the influence of another parameter on the relation between x and y. When predictors are correlated, they potentially have shared or overlapping explained variance in Y. We need to consider the unique contribution of each. Pearson’s correlation coefficient (r) does NOT do this. Squaring an r statistic is only useful when there is only one predictor (R-squared) Unique correlations are needed to account for multiple predictors: Partial (first-order) Correlation Semi-partial (part) Correlations

Partial (First-Order) Correlations The correlation between x and y while controlling for x2 (on both x and y)
Semi-Partial (Part) Correlation The correlation between x and y while controlling for x2 (on x1 only) The relative strength of the association between x and y. Squaring the partial correlation yields the proportion of the variance in Y remaining after removing the effects of all other predictors (Not very useful) Squaring the semi-partial correlation yields the proportion of the variance in y uniquely explained by x while controlling for all other predictors.
Useful as a measure of Effect Size x and y are unrelated before and after No variables are related to each other The relation between x and y remains stable x2 is irrelevant The relation between x and y drops to zero x2 completely accounts for the variation between x and y Signs of confounded predictors, spurious correlation, 'complete' mediation, statistical suppression The relation between x and y becomes stronger or flips signs x2 and x are so strongly related that findings become masked/suppressed The relation between x and y becomes smaller but still significant x only partly accounts for the variation in y Most common! Predicting variation in an outcome variable (y) based on changes in predictor variables (x1, x2, etc.) Can be simple (one y, one x), or multiple (one y, many x's) Can be simultaneous (all x's predicting y at the same time) or hierarchical (x's predicting y in pre-determined blocks)
Regular Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression assumes that x and y are linearly related and are normally distributed. Special cases require special analyses. The sample regression coefficients are statistics They are estimates of the population values of variable effects on y (how much variation in y is predicted by changes in x) Different samples will yield different values for the regression coefficients
Known as Sampling Error Coefficients are estimates, and therefore always include some error We want to minimize this error Parameters can be unstandardized (useful for raw interpretation) or standardized (useful for comparing parameters to each other) Unstandardized (b) coefficients are in the original scale and must be interpreted as a function of the original units. It is in the units you started with.

Standardized (𝛽) coefficients are based on z-scores (distances in Standard Deviation (SD) units from the mean) and can be compared across parameters.

The values of all parameters are influenced by the other parameters in the model. b0 (the intercept) Predicted score on y when all predictor variables are at zero. b1 (the slope of x1) The change in predicted y values for every 1 unit increase in x1 (holding x2 constant) b2 (the slope of x2) The change in predicted y values for every 1 unit increase in x1 (holding x1 constant)
When more than one predictor variable is included (either continuous or categorical) Often one of three types
Simultaneous Multiple Regression (E.g., all predictors at once)
Hierarchical Multiple Regression (e.g., variables added by research in theory-driven blocks)
Stepwise Multiple Regression (e.g., significant variables added in first or last; data driven) Regression coefficients for each predictor are 'partial,' in that they control for any other predictors present in the model (they 'control' for other parameters) All predictors are added at once All parameters control for all other parameters R-squared is one static value that represents the variance explained in the outcome variable by the collective set of predictors
Continuous Variable added as is
Nominal Variable must be dummy coded Variables with non-zero values should be 'centered' Predictors are added in theory-driven blocks (e.g., social-ecological models) A series of multiple-regression are performed, with each block being added to the next until all variables are included The final block of hierarchical multiple regression = simultaneous multiple regression Very useful to look at change in R-squared for each variable or blocks of variables Squared semi-partial correlation provides the unique variance explained by a given variable. Predictors are added in data-driven blocks
Forward Stepwise Regression Most predictive variables are added first
Backward Stepwise Regression Least predictive variables are trimmed Mathematically derives the highest R-squared value with the least number of predictors. NEVER USE THIS METHOD UNLESS STUDY IS ABSOLUTELY EXPLORATORY
Squared Semi-Partial (Part) Correlation Adjusted R-squared values Standardized regression coefficients Standardized coefficients are harder to interpret but more meaningful with multiple predictors (and there almost always are). Change in R-squared represents the amount of unique variance each block of variables explains above and beyond the other variables already included.
Random Sampling is preferable, but also less feasible (biased estimates) Reliable measurement of constructs is crucial, and checking psychometric properties of scales is important! Check for assumptions Linear Associations
Normality (Testing for Normality)
Multicollinearity (Multicollinearity) Check descriptive statistics and correlations between all included variables Confirm missing value codes Three core pieces of information for every data set you open: Number of cases Number of variables Date of last manipulation

Dependent Y variable Block Use next and previous buttons for blocks of variables Independent(s) x-variables Method Allows you to use stepwise, never use this Always use paste to send the analysis to the syntax editor and save your work.
Include Model Fit, R-squared change, Descriptives, Part and Partial Correlations, and Collinearity Diagnostics Confidence intervals are not necessary but can be helpful.
You can save residuals as their own variables to detect multivariate outliers. Predicted values tell you what SPSS thinks the y value should be based on the x-values of the case. Residual values are how far off SPSS was Mahalanobis distance tells you how far away a case is from the 'cloud' of other values.
Correlation tables are clunky in regression output. Generate them separately. Variables entered/removed only relevant when doing stepwise (ignore otherwise)
R-square tells you the proportion of variance explained in y by all of your x variables. Adjusted R-square takes sample size into account (weighting). Often not used.
R-squared changed useful for Hierarchical Multiple Regression. Shows how much more variance in y was explained by additional x variables (in the next block) Sig. F change signifies if the block significantly improved variance predictions.
Standard f-table that signifies if the omnibus test is significant (useful for parenthetical stats in manuscripts)
Where the action is. Each row conveys information about the regression equation that SPSS produced as the 'best fitting' model. Unstandardized coefficients are easier to interpret, but standardized coefficients are more useful for including in manuscripts (apples to apples instead of apples to oranges) Significance level of .05 is standard, though more stringent p-values can be employed to address weaknesses in design. Zero-order correlations represent the standard correlation between each x and y Partial and part correlations should be squared manually prior to interpretation. Squared partial correlation represents the variance remaining in y after factoring out the x variable. Squared part (semi-partial) correlation represents the unique variance explained in y by the x variable. Tolerance reflects the proportion of the variance in x that is not predictable from other x predictor variables. 0-1 with zero meaning no new contribution and one meaning completely uncorrelated with the other predictors.
VIF indicates the degree of similarity between an x variable and at least one other x variable in the model. Scores of higher than 5 are seen as evidence of Multicollinearity and action must be taken (e.g., variable removal or combining).

For Predictor (x) variables that are categorical, the standard procedure cannot be followed. The variable must be 'dummy coded.' Think of dummy coding as light switches. 1 ('on') means group membership and 0 ('off') means no group membership. Dummy coding means giving every case k-1 variables that indicate group membership. For the school variable So, someone from Cline elementary would have the following values for group membership: AEC = 0, Campbell County High = 0, Campbell County MS = 0, Campbell County Elementary = 0, Cline = 1, Crossroads = 0, Grants Lick = 0, Reiley = 0 k-1 groups are used to fully capture group membership. A 'reference' category is selected to represent group membership when all values are zero. Typically, the reference category is the most often selected category. For example, Campbell County High School has roughly 49% of the data in our sample dataset, meaning that category should be selected as the referent. Coefficients are interpreted as the mean differences between the reference category and the category in question.
Students in Campbell County Middle School have -.177 less global satisfaction than students at Campbell County High School, controlling for hope scores. The hat over y says we are looking at the predicted values. We are predicting y from x.
y = b0 + b1X1 + e (Simple Linear Regression (SLR))
y = b0 + b1X1 + b2X2 + ... + bnXn + e (Multiple Linear Regression (MLR))
y hat is our outcome variable (Dependent Variable)
x is our Predictor (Independent Variable)
b is our slope (Regression Coefficient s) b0 is our y-intercept Analyze -> Regression -> Linear
Drag Outcome variable into the 'Dependent' box > drag the Predictor variable into the 'Block 1 of 1' box In the Statistics menu, select Estimates, Confidence Intervals, Model Fit and Descriptive. “Linear Regression Analysis in SPSS.png” could not be found. Click on Paste to generate the syntax rxy = .448 “Linear Regression SPSS Output.png” could not be found. “Linear Regression SPSS Output 2.png” could not be found. Multiple R = corr (y, y-hat)
In Simple Linear Regression (SLR), Multiple R = |rxy|
R2 is the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable (y) that can be explained (accounted for) by the Independent Variable (s)/ Predictor (s) in the model (x's).
In SLR, R2 equals the square of the Pearson correlation between x and y (r2). 44.8% of variation Kid's score on cognitive test is accounted for by their mothers IQ.
The Omnibus test results in the ANOVA table shows that the model significantly predicts the Dependent Variable, (F(1,432) = 108.643, p < .001).
Constant (b0) 25.8 Slope (Regression Coefficient) (b1) .61 Estimated Model Kid's Score = 25.8 + 0.61 (Mother's IQ) Intercept (b0) At mom's IQ score of zero, the predicted kid's score is 25.8. Regression Coefficient (b1) For every unit increase (or decrease) in mom's IQ score, kid's score is predicted to increase (or decrease) by .61 unites. Do we have an IQ of zero? Sometime, interpreting the intercept becomes difficult or meaningless, especially when we are dealing with variables like IQ, SAT scores, etc. We have to use what is termed as 'mean-centering' That is creating a new variable by simply subtracting the mean from each individual observation E.g., Centered IQi = IQi - IQ-bar (mean of IQ scores) ** Centering mom_iq. ** Note that the mean for mom's IQ is 100 COMPUTE iq_c = mom_iq - 100 ** Running a simple linear regression using the centered variable REGRESSION /DEPENDENT kid_score /method=ENTER iq_c
Slope does not change (b1 = .610) The predicted kid's score when mom's IQ score is at the mean (i.e., 100) is 86.797. The interpretation of the intercept now makes more sense. REGRESSION /DESCRIPTIVES CORR SIG N /DEPENDENT kid_score /method=ENTER iq_c mom age.
Intercept (b0) At mom's IQ score of zero, the predicted kid's score is 25.8. Regression Coefficient (b1) For every unit increase in mom's IQ score, kid's score is predicted to increase by .6 units. Regression Coefficient (b2) For every one unit increase in mom's age, kid's score is predicted to increase by .39 units. Useful when we want to know the contribution of each variable to the model.
R2 change is not statistically significant Under Model Summary, row 2 (Model 2), under R2 (.003, p = .235) The R2 of .204 for Model 2 indicates that mom's age accounts for the additional .003 variation in kid's score after accounting for the variance explained by mom's IQ. This change is however not statistically significant (p = .235). In other words, mom's age did not significantly improve the model.
In order to ensure Model Parsimony, mom's age can be dropped from the model (i.e., maintain Model 1) REGRESSION /DESCRIPTIVES CORR SIG N /STATISTICS COEFF OUTS CI (95) R ANOVA CHANGE /DEPENDENT kid_score /method=ENTER iq_c /method=ENTER mom_age. Multicollinearity can be checked using
Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) Using variance proportion and condition index Mostly reported in articles Smaller VIF values indicate no meaningful collinearity (< 4 or < 10 if being conservative) VIF = 1/tolerance 1 / .884 = 1.131 in the example below
Our model can be said to be free from multicollinearity since the VIF value for all Independent Variable s are below cutoff value of 4.

Condition Index A way to summarize the size of each eigenvalues relative to largest eigenvalue
If condition index is greater than 30 AND more than one Predictor loads (or correlates) (> .4) on a single variance proportion, these together signal a potential multicollinearity problem. When assessing multicollinearity with the collinearity diagnostics, report on both the variance proportions and the condition indexes.

university-resources/current/glm-2/in-cl.title: 4. Diagnostics and Psychometrics
university-resources/current/glm-2/in-cl.description:
Linearity Linear relationships between Predictor and Outcome Normality of Errors Residuals in the model are random and normally distributed Homoscedasticity
The Variance of the residuals for all variables should be the same or similar Independence of Errors The residuals for all variables should be independent (uncorrelated) Lack of generalizability Potentially biased or inaccurate findings Delays or rejections of manuscripts with faulty analyses included But assumptions are easily (and often) violated. Correct when you can and be transparent when you cannot. Do not let assumption violations alone preclude your use of a statistical technique. Variables must be linearly related to each other Can be visually inspected via bivariate scatterplots (but be aware of limitations of mean averages based on Likert-type scales) Relations may be quadratic or cubic Biased estimates that lead to faulty interpretations Nonsignificant p-values, which may be hiding interaction effects What to do: Inspect each pair of variables and consider potential interaction effects Consider mathematical transformations to improve linear relations Revise the model with variables that are linearly related (model trimming) Histogram of Errors
Should be symmetrical and bell-shaped Normality Probability Plot
Dots should be on the diagonal Expected vs. Actual cumulative probability Plots of Standardized predicted values and residuals
Points should be randomly and even dispersed (flat) Estimates of variable effects are unbiased, but tests are flawed. Outliers may go unidentified Validity of interpretations may be questionable Transformations
If outliers or outlier-groups (special education students mainstreamed), may want to include group membership as an additional Predictor.
Equal residual variances for all Predictor variables. Plot of predicted values and residuals can shed light on this.


The standard errors and the statistical significance of variables are potentially invalid. If severe, or if samples are small, there could be a large degree of bias. Consider interaction terms WLS = Weighted Least Squares Weighted observations by precision. Precision is related to square of the residual for each case. Variables (and their residuals) should be uncorrelated and independent. If dependent, other approaches are necessary (e.g., dependent samples t-test, repeated measures, etc.)
Dependence may be caused by clustered/nested data (students within schools, clients within clinics) or lack of Autocorrelation (time-related or longitudinal data).
Invalid Standard Error s, Confidence Intervals, and significance tests. Durbin-Watson test Test for serial correlations between errors (should be close to 2).
An inflated (too high) correlation between Predictor variables. Ideally, predictors would be independent and uncorrelated, but this is not feasible. Can be detected by examining correlations table for high correlations, tolerance, VIF, and other collinearity diagnostics.
Standard Error s for variable effects (slopes) become quite large
T-Test s and F-Tests become unreliable and confidence intervals likely to contain 0 (Type II Errors inflation) Centering (in polynomial or interaction models) Deleting or combining variables (easiest, but last resort) Can be detected using residual diagnostics Useful for detecting bivariate outliers and multivariate outliers. Why is an observation extreme? Extreme responses may be an error or an honest response. Care should be take in what is done with extreme outliers (have a rationale) Univariate outliers
Boxplots, Frequency Distribution, Z-Score, Stem-and-Leaf plots, etc. Multivariate outliers
Mahalonobis' distance (Chi-Square Test), standardized residuals, leverages, cook's distance How far a case is from some point of reference
Mahalonobis' Distance
Identifies the distance of cases from the Mean (s) of Predictor (s). Extreme cases in multivariate space are found via a cut-off point (critical value of chi-square). Standardized Residuals
Measure the distance between an observed value and its predicted value that have all been converted to z-scores. Typically flag cases if they are 2 or 3 Standard Deviation (SD) s away from the mean.
How far a point deviates from the Mean of that variable Gauges the influence of the observed values over the predicted values. Ranges from zero to (N - 1) / N The average value is (k + 1) / n No greater than 2 (k + 1) / n or 3 (k + 1) / n The degree to which a variable can 'pull' the regression towards itself
Cook's Distance Measures the overall influence of a case on the model. Typically flagged if value is over 1.
Know your data well Know your model well Ensure enough time to verify assumptions so you are not trying to interpret a flawed analysis Delete, trim, or combine cases with extreme care Understand the implications of model revisions Be honest and transparent when writing up your findings The theory and technique of tests and measurements An often overlooked (and yet frequently asked for) element of research methods is the psychometric properties of the scales / measures used Any self-reported measure of any construct has psychometric properties that can be good, fair, or poor A basic understanding of psychometric statistics and how to generate them is crucial for inferential statistics Statistical Reliability
Test-Retest Reliability This is how well the measure provides the same or similar scores across time
Internal Consistency This is the consistency of responses within items on a multiple-item measure For our purposes, internal consistency is the most relevant
Statistical Validity
Glossary/Face Validity When the measure appears to measure what it is supposed to measure 'on its face'
Content Validity When the measure covers the construct of interest
Criterion Validity Scores on one measure correlate with scores on other measures that are logically (or theoretically) related to each other Known as concurrent validity when cross-sectional and predictive validity when longitudinal or panel design
Discriminant Validity Scores on one measure are distinct from scores on another measure that should (logically and theoretically) be independent We can analytically test ALL of these components. Measures the internal consistency of a construct based on the items entered The higher the value, the more 'tightly' the items fit together Cut-off values are debatable and depend on goals of the analysis, but generally accepted that > .80 is good reliability Mathematically derives the dimensionality or 'structure' of a set of items Helps to determine the underlying constructs represented by the data Ideally, the factor structure derived from the items will match theoretical expectations Importantly, EFA is data-driven We are asking the software to tell us where the data falls
Confirmatory Factor Analysis is used when we already known the factor structure and want to confirm its fit to the data For the Scree plot, all other factors not included after extraction would be considered 'suppressed.'

This is a measure of influence Cook's D greater than 1 is a cause for concern Cases with Cook's D greater than 1 have to be examined again because such cases are very likely to affect the regression model
Cook's Distance - .036 - If the maximum value is greater than 1, check the 'COO_1' for the case with the Cook's D greater than 1
Mahal Distance helps identify high leverage cases A High Leverage case is a case that is more extreme with respect to the independent variables Although High Leverages cases are less likely to affect the regression model, it is worth examining
You can test for the significance of Mahal Distance by using Chi-Square Test The degrees of freedom in this case is the number of predictors.
Mahal. Distance = 8.347

1 - CDF.CHSQ(MAH_1,2) Degrees of freedom is 2 because we have two predictors According to Tabachnick & Fidell (2013), the recommended threshold p-value is .001. So, cases with p-values less than .001 indicates significant outliers on the predictors.

The minimum p-value in this example is .02 which is greater than the threshold value (i.e., .001), so we can conclude that there is no significant outlier on the predictors.
The scatterplot shows an inverse relationship between Mahal Distance and the associated p-values. So, if the p-value of the maximum Mahal distance (Check the 'Residual Statistics Table') is greater than the threshold of .001, you can conclude that there is no significant outlier on the predictor(s). You do not even have to check the Mahal distance for individual cases. The absolute values of DfFITS (i.e., |SDF_1|) tells us the magnitude of the effect an individual case have on the predicted values. This indicates that, the SDF_1, similar to the Cook's distance, help examine the influence of some cases on the predicted values. Cases with absolute values of DfFITS greater than 2 (i.e., |SDF_1| > 2) should be examined.

Since the maximum absolute value is .33205, which is not greater than 2, we can conclude that there is no issue with an influential outlier(s). Helps examine whether a case is influential on the intercept or the slopes. The case should first be considered influential by looking at the D and/or the DfFITS. A case with an DfBeta greater than 2 can be said to have greater influence on the regression parameter in question (Pituch & Stevens, 2016). This case then has to be investigated.
In our example - SDB0_1 represents the DFBETA for the intercept - SDB 1_1 represents the DFBETA for the mom's IQ - SDB 2_1 represents the DFBETA for the mom age
The maximum absolute DFBETA (i.e., |DFBETA|) value for all the regression parameters (i.e., the intercept and the slopes) are less than 2, hence we can conclude that none of the cases have relatively high influence on our regression parameters.

university-resources/current/glm-2/in-cl.title: 5. Conditional Process Analysis
university-resources/current/glm-2/in-cl.description:
Disordinal (when the moderation slopes cross) An interaction/moderation occurs when the effect of an independent variable (x) on an Outcome variable (y) depends on the values of another independent variable (w).

Controlling for the other predictors in a model, does x predict y? The above is logical only if the relation between x and y does not depend on another predictor in the model. If a relation does depend on a moderating variable (w), then moderation has occurred and the relations need to be explored.
Moderation can occur between categorical predictors, categorical and one continuous predictor, or between continuous predictors. How you decide if its a moderator? If x and y AND w and y we know are related, we could include in the moderation. Categorical & Categorical

Continuous & Categorical

Continuous & Continuous
Model will be misspecified Inflates the MSE residuals F-test will be invalid (F = MSR / MSE) Mathematical transformation of variables to center around the mean instead of zero (e.g., making the mean equal zero) Subtract the mean of a variable from all observations for that variable.
Increases interpretability and decreases Multicollinearity Changes the interpretation of the intercept The value of the dependent variable when the independent variables are at their averages rather than zero. Debated in the literature, so choose for yourself what makes the most sense. Just report it correctly! Pro mean centering (Aiken & West, 1991) Against mean centering (Hayes, 2018)
A mediation (indirect effect) occurs when an Independent Variable (x) relates to an outcome variable (y) through a mediating variable (m).
a = first-stage relation (effect of x on m) b = Second-stage relation (effect of m on y) c = total effect (e.g., regression/correlation coefficient) c' = Direct effect (effect of x on y controlling for m) Indirect effect = a x b (a multiplied by b) The effect of x on y does not need to be significant for a mediation to be possible (e.g., x significantly relates to m, which significantly relates to y, but x does not predict y directly)
Multiple mediators may be present operating either in tandem (Parallel Mediation) or in sequence (Serial Mediation) Parallel Mediation
Controls for two covariates Serial Mediation
It is possible that x and y are not direct (partial or complete mediation) The examination of both moderation and mediation processes occurring at the same time.
Mediations can be moderated Index of mediation = a value of the distance between two indirect effects If significant, evidence of moderated mediation. If not significant, mediation is not moderated.
If you want to replicate the findings of an ANOVA via Regression exactly, be sure to code your Nominal Variable s around zero (-1, 1, or -. 05, .05) to achieve Main Effects Parameterization. This yields coefficients that represent the main effects of predictor variables.
Using Simple Effects Parameterization (0, 1) yields the same interpretation as dummy coding. The effect of x when w = 0, or the effect of w when x = 0. Which one to choose is a matter of preference and what research question (s) and hypotheses you are trying to address.
A tool developed by Andrew Hayes to easily run Conditional Process Analysis
Download files at (Download - The PROCESS macro for SPSS, SAS, and R) or from our Carmen site Extract all files from the zipped folder and move files to somewhere you can easily access Process y=outcome/x=independent/m=mediators/w=moderator/z-second moderator/cov=covariate list/model number from Hayes text/seed = any number you want that locks the random number generator. PROCESS includes 5000-sample bootstrapped confidence intervals by default
Conf = 99 increases to 99% confidence interval, which is more conservative. Useful for biased estimates, non-normal data, Multicollinearity, etc. You MUST include seed = some number so that the findings remain the same. If the random number generator is allowed to freely draw, the findings will be different every time. For moderation
For mediation
For Conditional Process Analysis
Scenario We want to find out whether the effect of mom's IQ on kid's score on a cognitive test is impacted by mom's high school status. In simple terms, do mother's high school status moderate the relationship between mother's IQ and kid's performance on a cognitive test? Model 1
Analyze -> Regression -> PROCESS v 4.2 by Andrew F. Hayes - Note: Make sure each variable name is not more than 8 characters

Drag the Dependent Variable into the 'Y variable' box (kid_score)
Drag the Independent Variable to the 'X variable' box (mom_iq) If you have any covariate(s), move it to the covariate(s) box
Drag the Moderator to the 'moderator variable w' box (mom_hs) Remember not to use the 'Paste' button! - If you want to use the syntax, you will have to generate the syntax by yourself.

If your Moderator or Independent Variable (x) is Categorical, click on 'Multicategorical' and select the coding scheme of your choice. A variable specified as 'Multicategorical' must have at least 3 categories.
You don't have to manually recode your Nominal Variable s. Process y = kidscore/ x=mom_iq/ w=mom_hs/ model=1/ center=2/ plot=1. Code Generated for the Graph
You will have to copy the 'DATA LIST FREE/' and to the period and paste into your syntax window
Although there is a positive effect of mom_iq on kidscore, the magnitude of the effect (the slope) is higher for children whose parents did not graduate high school (the blue line). Let's say that we have a theory that the more time you spend with a puppy, the happier you are. Also, the amount of love you have for puppies will moderate that effect. We will use the puppy_love dataset to run this scenario in PROCESS, but there are a few things to note: Make sure all variables you are using are 8 characters or less in length We will also set up the problem to create a plot We are interested in any points of W (the moderator) where the significance changes. This will be determined by the Johnson-Neyman approach. Go to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS
Move over your y, x, and w variables. Typically, we would change the model #, but given that we are working with Model 1, we are keeping it the default of 1. Click on 'Options'
This is the Options pop-up. To generate the code for making your plot, select Generate code for visualizing interactions. To get Johnson-Newman results, click on the box that is circled below for 'Johnson-Newman Output' Click Continue then OK Process y = Happy/ x= Dose/w=puplove/model=1/center=0/jn=1/plot=1/moments=0. Jn=1 We want to get the Johnson-Newman output, if any. Jn=0 Omitting it from the syntax means we do not want the J-N output. Plot=1 We want the syntax for the plot to be provided to us. Plot=0 Omitting it from the syntax means we do not want the syntax. Model=1 The simplest model where we have one moderator moderating the relationship between the focal predictor and the outcome variable. Please check the 'Appendix A' document for Process Macro to learn more about other models and their numbers. Moments=1 We want to create three categories of the moderator by using the mean, 1 SD above the mean, and 1 SD units below the mean (the most common approach).
(NB: only do this when your moderator is a continuous variable) This is done to help with interpretation Moments=0 Omitting it from the syntax means we are creating three categories of the moderator by using the 16th percentile, 50th percentile, and the 84th percentile. This is the default. If your moderator is a categorical with more than 2 categories, you can add /MCW=1 to the syntax to automatically create dummy variables for you. Check the appendix file for other coding schemes and their corresponding numbers. Center=0 Omitting it from the syntax Means NO CENTERING Center=1 All variables that define products should be automatically mean-centered Center=2
Only the continuous variables that defines products should be automatically mean-centered. Recommendation, if you are thinking about mean-centering, then:
Choose Center=2, if the moderator or the focal predictor is a continuous variable.
Choose Center=1 if both the moderator or the focal predictor are a continuous variables. Choose Center=0 if both the moderator or the focal predictor are a categorical variable
This first part of the output shows us the model we built including the model number, our N, and the model summary. Model summary includes the R2 value, which in this case shows a significant amount of variance explained (37.63%) Below, in the 'Model' table, you can see the coefficients for the intercept as well as for the slopes of Dose, Love of Puppies, and the automatically created interaction term. Just below that you see that the interaction term is dose x puppylove
This next significant table shows us the conditional effects of W at the 16 th, 50 th, and 84 th percentiles. Here, we see that when puppy love is at the 16 th percentile (puppy love = 1), the effect is 1.81 (p = .0013). Likewise, when puppy love is at the 50 th percentile (2.5), the effect is also significant (p = .0046) at 1.1694. However, the effect is no longer significant at the 84 th percentile for puppy love, (p > .05).
The next table is the Johnson-Newman results. The Johnson-Newman approach looks for the values of W, where the p-values of the conditional effect changes to above/below the chosen significance level (. 05). So, it looks for the values of W that cause t-crit value to equal zero for when determining the conditional effect of X, where the p-value is exactly the alpha, or .05 in most cases. At what values of W, do the results go from significant to non-significant, or vice-versa, in terms of conditional effect? Your results can either be of one, two, or zero values. If there is one value, that means there is only one value of W where the conditional effect either becomes significant or loses significance. If there are two values, that means there are two points at which W will change in significance. This will either mean the middle range is significant, but not the high and low values of W, or that the high and low values of W are significant, but not the middle range. The middle range is determined by the W values themselves. If there are no values, then the conditional effect is either always significant or never significant for all values of W. Next are graphical representations for what different types of Johnson-Newman results may look like. Where the line cross .05, that's where this approach looks for the value of W, giving us more insight into what extent our moderator... Well, moderates.
Graphs for two or no solutions to JN approach

See that the Johnson-Newman technique gave us only one value, 3.3364. By finding the value in the table below, we can see that the conditional effect is significant before W = 3.3364, but non-significant after that point. So, it is significant with lower levels of puppy love. (First column, row 3.3364)
The moderator (puplove) has significant impact on the relationship between time spent with Puppies and Happiness, only at its low values (i.e., from 0.00 to 3.3364) This implies that, the less an individual loves a puppy, the more time spent with puppy affect (increases) their happiness. At its higher values, the moderator (puplove) does not have a significant effect on the relationship between time spent with Puppies (focal predictor) and Happiness (outcome variable) This implies that, increasing the time spent with Puppy does not affect/change (increases) happiness for individuals who already love Puppies. The next part of the table give us the syntax to generate the plot
Double click on the matrix table and it will allow you to highlight and copy parts of the text. Highlight and copy from the DATA LIST FREE/ until the period at the end. Once you copy the code, paste it into a new syntax file. There is nothing you need to change. Just highlight and play the syntax. The results will look like the graph below, a plot with points but no lines.
To create plot lines, double click on the plot itself. A 'Chart Editor' pop-up will appear.
Click on the Add lines at Subgroups button (It looks like a scatterplots with TWO lines through it, not one) (circled in red) You will get the properties pop-up now, but by default, it will give you the lines you need, as you can see now in the red boxed area. Just close the properties box and the chart editor box.
This is what your chart should look like now. You can now have lines that can help you to visualize the changes in X vs. Y, given the subgroups of W. Pretend that literature shows that the more someone loves puppies, the happier they are. We would like to test that theory, but with a moderator of time spent with puppies during a trial (dose). Here, we are recognizing that Dose is a multi-categorical variable for control group (0 minutes, 15 minutes, or 30 minutes with puppies). Typically, we would need to dummy-code these variables, but PROCESS does it for you, provided you remember one extra step. First, set up the model as usual in PROCESS. Note. Where the variables are in the image based on the new hypothesis. Next click on 'Multicategorical'
The next pop-up you will get is the multicategorical box. Here, you will select the checkbox under 'Variable W' to indicate that your moderator is multicategorical. Note. The other options, indicating that you can also do this for any X or Z variables(s) that have 3 or more categories. Click Continue.
Click OK. One of the changes is the dummy coding. The coding scheme is provided just below the model overview and will look something like the table below.
The next change is the model and product terms key tables. Just keep in mind the W coding scheme from before when interpreting each line, since now we are recognizing the separate levels of our W. The final change is the set-up of the conditional effects table. Usually, this will either be representative of the 16 th, 50 th, and 84 th percentile (default), or the means +/- 1 SD (if selected). However, now since we are recognizing W as a categorical variable, the doses are listed as the separate categories. - Note how there is no mention of the percentiles in the 'Analysis Notes and Errors' section.

university-resources/current/glm-2/in-cl.title: 6. Analysis of Covariance (ANCOVA)
university-resources/current/glm-2/in-cl.description:
ANOVA tests the mean difference across at least 3 groups Compares the ratio of explained/between and unexplained/within Variance
In regression, ANOVA is a model in which there is one Categorical Predictor (kind of)

ANOVA, plus covariate (e.g., Covariance), traditionally a Continuous Variable By including a covariate, we can reduce error variability and account for confounds. It indicates differences in means are 'adjusted' for differences on the covariate.
Covariates can be anything relevant to your study, but should be correlate with you Dependent Variable. Example A study on how to build a laptop Suppose we have an experiment with 3 instructional groups and one covariate Instruction from a Mentor Instruction from a YouTube video No instruction at all
Dependent Variable: skill level on how to build a laptop before training (pe-test) By adding a covariate, differences in pre-test are 'removed' (controlled for) from the error term and means are adjusted to the predicted post-test level if all cases had the same skill level going into the study.
ANOVA is performed on the adjusted Dependent Variable scores Research Question
Do groups differ on the Dependent Variable after adjusting for pre-existing differences on the covariate?
In the test of means, we use the F-test
If the covariate explains some of the between-group differences in the Dependent Variable, the MSE (error) will be smaller. As the error term becomes smaller, the F-test for the effect (e.g., group differences) will become larger (in comparison), and thus more likely to become statistically significant.
Covariates do not guarantee statistical significance, and may make the primary Predictor less significant if they eat enough explanatory variance from the predictor variable (more on this in the assumptions section)
Regression What is the nature of the relationship between x2 and y?
ANOVA
Are there differences in means on y based on x1 (when Categorical)?
ANCOVA (Regression x ANOVA) After adjusting for differences due to x2, are there differences in y based on x1. Actual Means (in red)
Adjusted Means (in blue)

Same assumptions as Multiple Regression
Testing Linearity
Testing for Normality
Testing Homoscedasticity
Testing the Independence of Error
Independence between covariate and the Categorical Predictor (often violated)
Homogeneity of Regression (HOR) No interaction between the covariate and the categorical predictor/grouping variable
Covariate and Dependent Variable should be linearity related. Can be assessed by scatterplots within groups and overall. a A basic model that compares group means
b The ideal scenario in which a covariate only accounts for unexplained variance in y.
c A more realistic scenario in which the covariate accounts for both explained variance from the predictor and unexplained variance.
Scenario C is most common, and explains why the predictor variable becomes less significant when the covariate is present.
When slopes are 'homogeneous,' the covariate adjusted means on the Dependent Variable provide an adequate and appropriate description of effects of 'treatment effects.' Treatment effects = difference between adjusted mean for a group and the overall mean of the DV Treatment effects should be the same regardless of covariate values (parallel lines) What slopes are heterogenous, HOR is violated, and treatment effects vary. This implies an interaction between the covariate and the predictor. The regression lines are no longer parallel, and alternatives to ANVOCA should be considered. This means the focus shifts to interaction/moderation rather than statistical control.
If the lines are not parallel, then the relationship between x and y depend on the value of the covariate (aka a Moderator!)


Related to linearity addumption of Multiple Regression, but with Dependent Variable and Covariate. Can be easily assessed via bivariate scatterplots. If violated, consider transformations of the data (e.g., centering) Analyze > General Linear Model > Univariate
Move your model variables into the appropriate positions (Fixed factor = Independent Variable) Select appropriate diagnostic information
EM Means > Display means for independent Variable (allows for pairwise comparison with covariate)
Run an ANOVA with the Independent Variable (x) predicting the Covariate (y) (Should NOT be significant)
Run the ANCOVA, but build custom terms to view the interaction between the Independent Variable and the Covariate (interaction should NOT be significant)
More about ANCOVA, see Field, 2009. Simply, an ANOVA with the inclusion of a covariate. Reasons for including covariates To reduce within-group error variance
This helps to more accurately assess the impact of the Independent Variable (SS explained) Elimination of confounds That is, variables (other than the experimental manipulation) that are known to influence the dependent variable can be partialed out.
The assumption of Homogeneity of Regression Slopes The relationship between the covariate and the outcome variable should be the same across groups. A simple scatterplot (with a regression line) showing the relationship between the covariate and the outcome variable can help verify this assumption. You can run the ANCOVA model by including an interaction term (groups x covariate). The interaction term should not be statistically significant. If it is statistically significant, then it means the slopes are different across groups, hence the violation of this assumption. UNIANOVA Dependent Variable BY Factor WITH Covar /METHOD=SSTYPE(3) /INTERCEPT=INCLUDE /EMMEANS=TABLES (Factor) WITH(COVAR=MEAN) COMPARE ADJ(Bonferroni) /PRINT ETASQ DESCRIPTIVE PARAMETER HOMOGENEITY /CRITERIA=ALPHA(.05) /DESIGN=itbsmc 2 treat. NB: you can also use the point-and-click method to generate the syntax. Click Analyze > General Linear Model > Univariate
Drag the Dependent Variable into the 'Dependent Variable' box. Drag the factor (grouping variable) into the 'fixed-factor' box. Drag the covariate into the 'Covariate' box. Note. This is for a simple model. There are other options available for a more complete analysis. We want to find out whether students WISC score differ across treatment groups after controlling for their score on itbsmc 2 (IOWA test of Basic Skills-Math concept). UNIANOVA WISC BY Treat WITH itbsmc2 /METHOD=SSTYPE(3) /INTERCEPT=INCLUDE /EMMEANS=TABLES (Treat) WITH (itbsmc2=MEAN) COMPARE ADJ (Bonferroni) /PRINT ETASQ DESCRIPTIVE PARAMETER HOMOGENEITY /CRITERIA=ALPHA(.05) /DESIGN=itbsmc2 treat.
The mean for the three groups are very close to each other (102.23; 101.96; 101.95; and 102.05)
The error of variance for the dependent variable (WISC) is equal across groups (p > .05) (Sig. = .167)
Hence, the assumption of Homogeneity of Variances has been met.
This is similar to the Testing Homoscedasticity assumption in MLR “6. Analysis of Covariance (ANCOVA)-2.png” could not be found. The explained sum of squares is 22,597.231. The unexplained sum of squares is 28,908.488 The total sum of squares is 51,505.719 The overall model is statistically significant, F(3,124) = 32.31, p < .001. The covariate (itbsmc 2) is statistically significant, with p < .001, Partial η2 = .439. The factor (treat) is NOT statistically significant, given p = .878, Partial η2 = .002 The R2 is .439, indicating that approximately 43.9% of the variation in children WISC score can be explained by the predictors.
1.201 = adjusted mean (treat=1) - adjusted mean (treat=3) -. 404 = adjusted mean (treat=2) - adjusted mean (treat=3)
The results are equivalents to that of MLR.
In ANCOVA, SPSS automatically uses the category coded with the highest value as the reference category. In this example, there were three categories so two dummy variables were created, and group 3 was used as the reference group. A unit increase in itbsmc2 will result in a .652 unit increase in children WISC score, holding other predictors constant. The dummy variables were not statistically significant (p > .05), indicating the absence of differences among the categories.
The adjusted means are slightly different from the unadjusted means. This is because the group means values have been adjusted for the effect of the covariate (i.e., itbsmc2)
None of the differences are statistically significant (p > .05) Not surprising because 'Treatment' was not statistically significant (check the 'Test of Between-Subject Effects' table).
The p-values were adjusted (using Bonferroni) to reduce the chance of committing Type I Errors arising from multiple comparison. Syntax: just add the interaction term (itbsmc2) to the model. UNIANOVA WISC BY Treat WITH itbsmc 2 /METHOD=SSTYPE (3) /INTERCEPT=INCLUDE /EMMEANS=TABLES (Treat) WITH (itbsmc 2=MEAN) COMPARE ADJ (Bonferroni) /PRINT ETASQ DESCRIPTIVE PARAMETER HOMOGENEITY /CRITERIA=ALPHA (. 05) /DESIGN=itbsmc 2 treat itbsmc 2 * treat. We do not want the interaction term to be statistically significant. If it is significant, then it implies that the relationship between the covariate and the outcome differs among the groups. In other words, the regression slopes are not homogenous. You can go to Graph > Scatterplot to create a simple scatter plot to visualize the relationship across groups before the analysis itself.
Create the scatterplot using the point-and-click method. The syntax generated by clicking the paste button: GRAPH /SCATTERPLOT (BIVAR)=itbsmc 2 WITH wisc BY treat /MISSING=LISTWISE.
Click on 'Add Fit Lines to Subgroups' to add the fit lines.
The regression slopes (lines) appear similar (homogenous) across groups.
The interaction term is NOT statistically significant (p = .425).
Hence, the assumption of HOR has been met.
Since we have a Nominal Variable, we will have to recode it. We will create k - 1 dummy variable (i.e., 2 dummy variables in this case) We will use the 'control' group as our reference group. ** Creating D 1RECODE treat (1=1) (2=0)(3=0) INTO D 1. VARIABLE LABELS D 1 'DIRECT'.EXECUTE.** Creating D 2RECODE treat (1=0)(2=1)(3=0) INTO D 2. VARIABLE LABELS D 2 'INQUIRY_BASED'. EXECUTE. The regression model y = b0 + b1 Covariate + b2D1 + b3 D2 + ε WISC = b0 + b1itbsmc2 + b2Direct + b3Inquiry_based + ε ** The Regression AnalysisREGRESSION /DESCRIPTIVES MEAN STDDEV CORR SIG N /MISSING LISTWISE /STATISTICS COEFF OUTS R ANOVA /CRITERIA=PIN (. 05) POUT (. 10) TOLERANCE (. 0001) /DEPENDENT wisc /METHOD=ENTER itbsmc2 D1 D2
The R2 is the same as what we had from the ANCOVA model. The explained (22,597.231), unexplained (28,908.488), and total (51,505.719) sum of squares are also the same as what we had from the ANVOCA model (check the 'Tests of Between-Subjects Effects' table from the ANCOVA results)
The regression coefficients are the same as what we had from the ANCOVA output (Check the parameter estimates table from the ANCOVA output/results) AKA Sequential Sum of Squares The order matters! Each effects partials out the one before it. So, if you are looking at a, b, and a x b The first value is for a The value for b is after controlling for a a x b's value is after controlling for a and b. Best for specific theory where order matters I.e., partial out certain variables first. a accounts for b and vice versa. This is best when you don't have an interaction effect. Every value accounts for every other effect (main or interaction) If order matters, Type I. If order does not matter, and there is no interaction, Type II. If order does not matter, but there is an interaction, Type III.
